fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An object C \in \mathcal {C} is said to be orthogonal to a morphism f\colon A\to B if for all g\colon A\to C, there is a unique h\colon B\to C making the following triangle commute:
When W is a collection of morphisms in \mathcal {C}, an object C \in \mathcal {C} is said to be orthogonal to W when C is orthogonal to every morphism in W.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category and W be a collection of morphisms in \mathcal {C}. The orthogonality class W^{\bot } is the full subcategory of \mathcal {C} spanned by objects that are orthogonal to W.
